title: 106_hr3504
content: The "CRA Restoration Act of 1999" is also known as the Community Reinvestment Amendments. The CRA Restoration Act of 1999, also known as the Community Reinvestment Amendments, amends the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 to require all subsidiary depository institutions of a financial holding company to have a satisfactory record of meeting community credit needs. The CRA Restoration Act of 1999 amends the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 to exclude newly acquired depository institutions from community needs requirements for a 12-month period under certain conditions. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 is amended to require a bank holding company to submit a plan to achieve a satisfactory community credit needs rating and have it accepted by the appropriate Federal banking agency. The Act also grants authority to impose limitations until specified conditions are corrected. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 now requires a bank holding company to submit a plan to address community credit needs and comply with imposed limitations until conditions are corrected. The Board and Federal banking agencies have the authority to impose appropriate limitations on company activities if necessary. The Bank Holding Company Act of 1956 requires a bank holding company to comply with imposed limitations and restore compliance within specified timeframes. Compliance with limitations can be enforced by the Board and Federal banking agencies. The Board may require a company to divest control of a subsidiary or cease certain activities, with possible extensions granted at the Board's discretion. Amendments to relevant sections of banking acts are also noted. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act amends various sections of banking acts, including the Community Reinvestment Act and the Revised Statutes of the United States. It includes requirements for national banks and their affiliates to be well capitalized, well managed, and have a satisfactory record of meeting community needs. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act amends banking acts, including the Community Reinvestment Act and the Revised Statutes of the United States, requiring national banks and affiliates to meet community credit needs. Newly affiliated depository institutions may have limited exclusions from these requirements. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act amends banking acts to require national banks and affiliates to meet community credit needs. Affiliated depository institutions may have limited exclusions from these requirements, subject to submitting an affirmative plan accepted by the appropriate Federal banking agency. The Act also repeals the CRA Sunshine Requirement and the Small Bank Stretch-Out provision. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires national banks and affiliates to meet community credit needs, with limited exclusions for affiliated depository institutions. It also repeals the CRA Sunshine Requirement and the Small Bank Stretch-Out provision.
